speaker: marcusgower

text: Good morning. Apologies, I'm not sure where my camera has gone to. That's OK. Ngā mihi nui ki a koutou, everybody.  My name is Dawn Pritchard. I'm a planner for Waipā District Council and the author of the report requesting a number of environmental benefit lots to be determined. Before I continue, is it OK that I use the acronym EBL in lieu of having to say environmental benefit lots? Is that OK? That's fine. Thank you. Thank you. I'll take my report as being read and we'll summarise the key points and happy to answer any questions thereafter. Great.  COGSWARES on behalf of Buchanan Farm Limited have written to Council and provided an ecologist report requesting six EBLs being awarded in exchange for the protection of five forest blocks located at 5 Bar 370 Aspen Road to Middle. These blocks have been described as regenerating indigenous scrub and forest remnants with predominant tawa  pūkātea, poutaka, broadleaves, scrub kahikatea and kānuka present. These blocks lie within two gully systems and cover approximately 18.12 hectares. Included for permanent protection is an additional one to almost three hectares of exotic grasses with some indigenous regeneration occurring.  Our streams flow through all five blocks, which provide really good fish habitat, and the blocks act as a stepping stone for indigenous birds, including Kiriru and Tui, to move between the district's larger reserves, and it was suggested that long-tailed bats are also likely present here. I undertook an assessment against relevant criteria in the district plan for EBLs,  and can confirm that with the exception of Block 5, the blocks are located within identified significant natural areas. With that being said, Block 5 will meet the criteria to become significant following some restoration. It was also confirmed that all of the blocks are entirely within the biodiversity corridor, specifically the indigenous forest corridor.  The applicant's ecology report from Blue Wattle was referred to council's ecologist, Boffa Miskell's Andrew Blaney. Mr. Blaney advised that the Blue Wattle report was well-written and agreed with the overall assessment that the blocks proposed to be protected do actually qualify for EBL entitlements and will result in significant biodiversity gains.  Mr Blaney concluded in his comments that he is too supportive of six EBL entitlements being awarded, more specifically five EBLs for blocks one to four and one EBL for block five once restored.  To sum up, and bearing in mind that the number of EBLs recommended to you this morning is consistent with other similar significant natural areas and EBLs awarded to that proposed, that in my opinion, due to the size of the forest blocks to be protected and having them identified as being significant with biodiversity values that will positively contribute to the public good, and more importantly, with the advice provided from council's ecologist,  that the overarching recommendation is for six EBL entitlements being awarded to the applicants, subject to those conditions in section seven of my report being met, which relates to a management and restoration report being provided at the time of any subsequent subdivision consent being applied for. I'm happy to take any questions.
